page.title: 04ASHPERTON: LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Ashperton is mentioned in the Domesday Book as Spertune, the prefix Ash may refer to nearby water. The farm Walsopthorne (called Wassington) is also listed as a separate manor, Walesapeldor (Waltheof's Apple Tree). There is a castle mound and moat near the church but the stone from the ruins had been removed and used for other local building by the end of the eighteenth century. The abandoned Herefordshire and Gloucestershire Canal passes N.E. of the village. It was completed in 1845 towards the end of the Canal Era but was hardly used, partly because of a meagre water supply. There remains an overgrown, deep cutting, a quarter mile length of tunnel and a lock-keeper's cottage which has been bought by a canal enthusiast and may be restored.
